content: <collection xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim">    <dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:invenio="http://invenio-software.org/elements/1.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:identifier>doi:10.5281/zenodo.10592</dc:identifier><dc:creator>Patel, Rahul</dc:creator><dc:creator>Metchev, Stanimir</dc:creator><dc:creator>Heinze, Aren</dc:creator><dc:title>Finding Warm Debris Disks with WISE Around Bright Stars</dc:title><dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject><dc:description><p>We present a sensitive search for&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 (12 &mu;m) and&nbsp;<em>W</em>4 (22 &mu;m) excesses from warm optically thin dust around&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;main sequence stars within 75 pc from the Sun. We use contemporaneously measured photometry from&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>, remove sources of contamination, and derive and apply corrections to saturated fluxes to attain optimal sensitivity to &gt;10 &mu;m excesses. We use data from the&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;All-Sky Survey Catalog rather than the AllWISE release because we find that its saturated photometry is better behaved, allowing us to detect small excesses even around saturated stars in&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>. Our new discoveries increase by 45% the number of stars with warm dusty excesses and expand the number of known debris disks (with excess at any wavelength) within 75 pc by 29%. We identify 220&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;debris disk host stars, 108 of which are new detections at any wavelength. We present the first measurement of a 12&nbsp;&mu;m and/or 22&nbsp;&mu;m excess for 10 stars with previously known cold (50-100 K) disks. We also find five new stars with small but significant&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 excesses, adding to the small population of known exozodi, and we detect evidence for a&nbsp;<em>W</em>2 excess around HIP&nbsp;96562 (F2V), indicative of tenuous hot (780 K) dust. As a result of our&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;study, the number of debris disks with known 10-30&nbsp;&mu;m excesses within 75 pc (379) has now surpassed the number of disks with known &gt;30 &mu;m excesses (289, with 171 in common), even if the latter have been found to have a higher occurrence rate in unbiased samples.</p></dc:description><dc:publisher/><dc:date>2014-06-18</dc:date><dc:source>http://zenodo.org/record/10592</dc:source><dc:doi>10.5281/zenodo.10592</dc:doi><dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10592</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10592</dc:identifier></dc:dc>   </collection>
